metadata.dc:author: Román Bassaure, E
Hernández Aten, D
Matías Salvador, M
Torres Lobatón, A
metadata.dc:description: This paper reports an analysis of 217 patients with invasive carcinoma of the cervix, treated with radical histerectomy at The Oncology Service, General Hospital of Mexico. The commonest complications of surgical procedure, were related with the urinary tract: atony bladder observed in 27.6% of patients, vesico-vaginal fistulas in 7.8% and uretero-vaginal fistulas, in 5.5%. Lymph node metastases were present in 20/143, (13.9%) patients classified as belonging to stage Ib and 10/51, (19.6%) of stage IIa, p less than 0.05. After a follow-up period of two years, 92/101, (91%) of patients in stage Ib, 24/32, (75%) in stage IIa, p less than 0.05, 69/73 with tumor less than 2 cm and 111/125, (88.8%) without lymph node metastases, were free of disease. A poor prognosis was related with tumor size of 4 cm or more, 12/18, 66%); adenosquamous carcinomas, (7/11, 63.6%); poorly differentrated carcinomas, (13/20, 65.8%) and lymph node metastases, (8/15, 53.3%).
metadata.dc:title: Histerectomía radical por cáncer cervicouterino. Experiencia con 217 pacientes.
[Radical hysterectomy for cervix uteri cancer. Experience with 217 patients].
